At the same time, the US market was balancing in the 36003800 range with a break to 3500 points 1H22 reports were known, as they are now for 1H24. Profits were down by a quarter in real terms with no successful reps in tech, and this was presented as a 20 trillion dollar success the difference in capitalization now and then. They could use some of those robots youll never see in your lifetime. I was promised flying cars....

I am 34 rn , not as old as you. I dont believe in granduer or anything but this from my personal exerience I didnt have a mobile phone till I was 15 or 16. I didnt have have internet , in fact computers were rare when I was in school. People said there wil be a time when everyone will have their own computer. It is funny right, that is what I listened to when I first operated a pc. We used floppy discs in school. The world has come a lot way since with Internet of things taking over. I dont need to think we will have massive AI during my lifetime, but it can happen after I am dead. The world has changed a lot since then , and it keeps changing. Tech keeps evolving. We do have flying cars but they are not feasible. I often think science fiction has roots in the real world and a lot of science fiction did come through in my lifetime. Back in my country, we used to stand in lines waiting at an international calling booth to make an international call, the charges were per second. Today , we have a screen , and we can see other people no matter where they live. The world has changed so much. Internet of things , touch screens of all devices and PCs everywhere, holograms, everything was the stuff of fiction.

As an American, let me tell you something... We had all that stuff you spoke of in the late 80s and early 90s. Your reality does not define actual reality... The bottom line is... Unless it gives someone important more control over population.it probably isnt happening...
Let me be more specific... Affordable flying cars... Not some modern twist on a plane or helicopter...
Do you think we will never achieve technological progress
Weve been progressing... Just not as fast as everyone likes to pretend were.

Just remember theres three rules to this game. 1 It has to make money. 2 If it makes money and never breaks or. improves... It doesnt make money. 3 It has to make money forever! Thats how the economic system of slavery works...

We used to progress faster than this in the early 1900s than we do right now btw. We have been quite slow compared to the past in the recent decades. A lot of tech today is also based on some innovations and theories like from a hundred years or so ago.
Which means... You need to make money to spend it.

This is an opinion not a fact. Innovation just happens when needed , I think. We have a new war, we innovate , we need to blow up people in a better way , we innovate. Thats just what I believe. Innovation happens when we need it , and profit is also one of those needs. We cured people from diseases because it was a need , not exactly profit. And we waste money in wars because it is needed. I live in the States btw , was not born here.
Thats because nothings really new... Its just reused and modernized...
For instance the first known GPS guided anything was a missile in 1938... Theyre now trying to use that same technology in self driving cars. So new and innovative...
No, innovation happens at the government level, and they just sell it to us when theyve got something new to play with.

All Im saying is just dont be shocked when tech hits a standstill for a decade or two. Thats pretty much how I felt until recently. Social media isnt new either... I talked to people on AOL in the late 80s. The cloud is nothing more than mass data collection centers. Which tells whomever whatever they need to know about you while simultaneously speeding everything up because the centers are closer to you. Back in the day, the closest data center couldve been several states away.

Last week, a poster out here said that Harris's tax hike proposals on investors only affects millionaires.Not true.The ONLY Harris investment tax proposal that affects only millionaires is her proposalto tax un-realized capital gains.  ALL of the rest of her proposals affect us more or less,depending on the regular, earned-income tax bracket we are in.

Here is what's at risk with taxes on us Investors in November's election:Kamala Harris and Biden together stated last winter that they would liketo tax long-term capital gains as "ordinary income". So, an HPE investorin a 24% tax bracket selling his stock would be taxed $2,400 instead of$1,500 for his $10,000 capital gain.But Harris/Biden also don't like Trump's 2017 tax cuts, so letting themexpire next year would turn a 24% marginal tax bracket into a 28% taxbracket and the stock sale would be taxed $2,800. That would almostDOUBLE it! Mr. Trump likes the LT gain tax right where it is at 15%.Harris/Biden have also stated that the top corporate tax rate (the one thataffects HPE the most) should be increased from 21% currently to 28%, anincrease of 33% on this company that would certainly hurt it's performanceand stock price.Mr. Trump wants to reduce the corporate rate from 21% to 15%. Like the LTgain tax proposals, Harris wants the rate almost DOUBLE what Mr. Trumpwants it to be.Harris also wants to tax un-realized gains for higher income investors. this new mandatory convertible preferred will increase the share count by about a max of 82 million shares on conversion in September of 2027 (3 years).  With the current share count of 1.3 billion that is at most about a 6% dilution.  You get paid an interest rate of 7.625% a year on your investment for the 3 years prior to mandatory conversion and then you get between 2.5 and 3.1 common shares for each preferred share you own.  That comes out to between 16 and 20 dollars a common share for each 50 dollar preferred share.  That's about what the current share price has been in the past 6 mo.   However HPE is going to have to borrow about 10 billion dollars to fund the total purchase price of 14 billion dollars in cash for Juniper Networks.  That's going to be a hefty price in interest on that loan.  What do others on this forum think?

Here is a rundown of policy differences. This is not an endorsement.Mr. Trump recently stated that he supports reducing the top corporate income tax bracketfrom 21% to 15% in order to help companies like HP to compete strongly against foreigncompetitors. 7 years ago, Mr. Trump spearheaded reducing the rate from 35% to 21%.Ms. Harris proposes increasing the top corporate rate from 21% to 28%, a 25% increase inincome tax HP would have to pay instead of investing in it's growth.Mr. Trump wants to maintain the current long-term capital gains tax on sales of HP stockat 15% and 20% for higher earners.Ms. Harris proposes taxing capital gains taxes as ordinary earnings. So an investor in the 28% marginal income tax bracket would see in increase in capital gains taxes on HP stock sales from 15% to 28%, almost doubling the tax owed. Ms. Harris also proposes, with Mr. Biden,to impose the tax on "unrealized" gains, on HP stock that an investor owns but has not yetsold. The unrealized gain tax would be imposed on higher earners.Mr. Trump lowered personal income tax brackets across the board in 2017. Those reductions will "sunset" (end) in 2025 if they are not renewed. Mr. Trump wants to renew them. Ms. Harris avoids the subject, but Mr. Biden has expressed disdain for the 2017 reductions. The increased standard deduction would also sunset. If the brackets sunset and increase to the pre-2017 levels, so too would the cap-gains tax with Harris's proposal.
